comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] 

Note the water sprayed on the tram tracks to reduce the dust ... photo taken 1899-1900 before the introduction of electric traction to the Pitt Street and Castlereagh Street routes

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: They must have thought this was colossal for it's time... this pre-dates any real notion of a train network surely?

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/86916510@N00] It was! In fact the Sydney Railway Company, precursor to the Government operations which surplanted the company was advocating moving the central railway station of the first line closer to the heart of the city as early as 1849.

Here is a map of the first planned extension

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/5353105184/in/faves-johncowper/]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Interesting article in the SMH of 3/1/1902 (p.3) one year before this photo, describing the progress and the amount of work involved in moving the hill where the cemetery was. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14446921 .

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Thanks, that's interesting to know the topography was changed so dramatically.

From the Trove link above:

"...Before the buildings surrrounding the cemetery 
were removed very few peoplo were aware of the
fact that the top of the hill referred to was very 
much higher than the platforms of the existing rail- 
way station. It was only when the buildings were
pulled down, and the public was able to get a glance 
at what had been to them a terra incognita for 
many years, that they were able to see that an im-
mense quantity of sand would have to be removed 
from the top of the lull in order to form the neces- 
sary plateau on which to erect the new station on a
level with the old one..."

comment.author: 36666393@N08
comment._content: My 4th Great Grandfather Michael McGrath is somewhere under there! Buried in an unmarked grave in the Devonshire St. Cemetery, by the time they were moving bodies to Botany there were no family members even aware he was buried there. I wonder did they try and find all the bodies or only those that were inquired about or where in an obvious marked grave?

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/36666393@N08]  That's sad. My great-great-great grandfather Rev William Cowper and his second wife Ann and daughter Isabella were buried there as well. When they were re-interred them at the time of the station development William went to St Jude's Randwick and Ann and Isabella went to Botany! Later William was joined by his sons William (Macquarie) and Sedgwick at Randwick. It's ironic though that the railway station proposed by another of William's sons (Charles when manager of the Sydney Railway Company) eventually split the family in death! Charles on the other hand rests with one of his sons and a daughter in London's Highgate Cemetery.

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: You are right about the dates of the top photo John. The Anthony Hordens buildings had a massive and deadly fire in 1901, destroying all of their amalgam of buildings over two adjoining blocks  and they then moved further up George Street to what is now World Square.
